author: Chris kitching
title: Friends shamed for 'abandoning' drunk woman outside nightclub with no money 'because she was an inconvenience'
text:
News Friends shamed for 'abandoning' drunk woman outside nightclub with no money 'because she was an inconvenience' The woman was left behind after she got so drunk that she was refused entry into the club Share Volunteers help the young woman outside the nightclub Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A community volunteer group has shamed a young woman's friends after they allegedly abandoned her during a drunken night out and put her at risk of violence. 
The woman was left behind after she got so drunk that she was refused entry into a nightclub and had trouble walking, it was claimed. 
She was cared for by volunteers from Cheltenham Guardians after she was found alone with no money shortly after 2am on Sunday. 
Concerned volunteers blasted the friends who ditched her because she was an "inconvenience", and raised fears that a woman in such a vulnerable state could be raped and murdered. Concerned volunteers blasted the friends in a Facebook post 
The community group in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, works with police and other agencies to provide care for people on the streets, including the homeless and revellers who have had too much to drink. Read More Maid of honour 'downed bottle of whisky, nearly ran over best man with his own car - then exposed herself to police' 
A mobile patrol located the woman after receiving a radio call from a nightclub on Promenade stating that a drunk woman needed help. 
A member of Cheltenham Guardians wrote on Facebook: "We quickly ascertained that 'Sarah' (not her real name) had been refused entry into the club as she was intoxicated and very unsteady on her feet. 
"We also learned that Sarah's friends were aware of her situation and had left her alone with no money whilst they continued on into the club. They abandoned her to the night. 
"Had vigilant door security or Guardians not been there for 'Sarah' any number of negative situations could have occurred such was her level of intoxication." 
Cheltenham Guardians said it learned that 'Sarah' was staying with a friend - named as 'Beth' in the Facebook post, although it is not her real name - who made it into the club. The Guardians have a protocol named for murder victim India Chipchase (Photo: Northamptonshire Police/PA) 
Security located and removed 'Beth' from the nightclub. 
The Facebook post stated: "It was clear to us when we met 'Beth' that she believed 'Sarah' to be an inconvenience. The club beckoned and Sarah's needs were secondary. Read More Mum-of-seven who glassed woman and scarred her for life is spared jail because of her children 
"Tiring a little of seeing situations such as this one Guardian Marian gave 'Beth' chapter and verse about looking after and not abandoning your friends when you are out. 
"We felt as though the message didn't get through. 'Beth' put 'Sarah' into a taxi and returned to the club." 
Facebook users joined in and slammed the woman's friends, with one writing: "Anyone who abandons an intoxicated friend is not truly a friend, but utter scum. Sarah - find yourself some new friends. You don't need these lowlives!" 
But some suggested that 'Sarah' should take some responsibility for her condition. 
One user wrote: "Nobody should get so intoxicated they cannot look after themselves. If she had no money why was she going into a club. 
"Always easy to keep pointing fingers but at the end of the day it's 18 to drink and your classed as an adult. So be responsible for your own actions." 
Volunteers said they have been dealing with an increase in cases where friends are abandoning friends on nights out, often leaving them with no money or way of getting home. Read More Emmerdale actor "blindsided" in horrific nightclub bottle attack as he tried to rescue girl being assaulted 
The group has an 'India Protocol' - named for 20-year-old India Chipchase, who was raped and murdered in Northampton last year - in which they approach every lone female they encounter after midnight to find out if they need help. 
Cheltenham Guardians said: "Our India Protocol means we will identify and deal with a good number of lone females but many will slip through the net. 
"One of these days an abandoned friend may never make it home, only to be found the next day by the police raped and murdered like India Chipchase. 
"Take responsibility for your friends. Look out for one another." Like us on Facebook
